CatDescriptText: Prentice Parrish, steel worker, 7242 Finance Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 15, 1959, pg. B1 with question: "Do you believe judges give society proper protection by refusing to send confessed murderers, guilty of murder in the first degree, to the electric chair?" answer reads: "I don't think so, because if the confessed murderer, who intended to kill, did not receive the electric chair, somebody else might say that he did it and got away with it, so I can do the same thing."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Prentice Parrish wearing dark cap, striped shirt, and cardigan with dark trim, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flowers, Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
